"I consider these Indians to be traitors to their own countries and I strongly believe that these Indians dream of being in any place other than India just so they can escape the harsh realities of India and not have to damage their conscience every day by turning a blind eye to what their motherland really is outside of Bollywod films and feel-good news stories about "India shining".

I think this type of rambling, angry, and utterly unintelligent opinion is what holds India back. If you go to Canada, you won't see extreme poverty in most cities, unless you travel to racially segregated "reserves" where the aboriginals live like the poor do in India: no school, malnutrition is high, and there's also harsh winters.

I remember going to Calcutta one year, and seeing a pile of garbage outside where I was staying. It bothered me, so I got up early one morning, bagged the garbage, and some neighbours in the community took the bags to the dump. For a brief moment in time, I made a very small difference in Calcutta's sanitation, even if it was fleeting. I think people who articulate angry, unintelligent ones like the one I quoted above would just point at the garbage, get angry, and blame their countrymen. In that case, you're the real traitor.

Incidentally, HBO movies pander to stereotypes about India because it makes the West feel better about itself. Everyone in India knows what poverty is, and watch movies to forget their problems and be entertained. That's a key difference.

I think to say that only westerners can portray India in a realistic light is ludicrous. It’s precisely this reason that people who live in India do not accept such opinions made by NRIs and foreigners who are heavily focused on portraying the discourse on India in a light that is very narrow and reflects a close mindset. We as Indians are not blind to the realities that our country is facing nor opposed to it being portrayed in the media. But all bollywood films are not about song and dance – there have been some poignant films about farmer suicide and sexual abuse and other such problems that are also prevalent in society in the Indian film industry. Believe it or not there’s more than just slums and call centers. It’s people whose knowledge of a vast and diverse country like India is limited by labels like decrepit and backward who are actually the ones that can’t accept that India is a dynamic and vibrant society despite the many problems that exist. All I’m trying to point out is that we shouldn’t place unrealistic labels, nor eulogise western filmmakers for their accurate depictions of India because there are more documentaries and films being made in India and they also deserve as much credit if not more.

So these pre concieved ideas will get minimised when these filmakers actually live in India for few months and may be there next film on Indian will be more objective and more "real".

While the world is fed with news about raging campaign against shameless corruption, it is not said in so many words that corruption has seeped down to the very roots of Indian society. Hence, it is widely acknowledged that no amount of legislation will end corruption. In this situation government should govern the least. And all cases of corruption by elected representatives of people and bureacracy should e decided by open people's court. Due process of law, as understood and practised by liberal west ,  can be invoked later. India is a huge  jungle. It should cease to exist in it's sub-continental size. Big India is unmanageable and has been breeding big corruption only.

Govt of India is trying its level best to help their employees in protecting them againt Anti Corruption Laws by diluting Lokpal bill as much as possible. Like every other employer, Govt is trying to buy loyalty of employees from any adverse legal action aganist corruption. The route is to have a weak "Enquirypal" and still keeping all the powers with Govt for taking the first real step. By blocking at first step, Govt gets to veto any investigation at entry level. This satisfies not only corrupt employees but also corrupt Govt ministers.

Does the technology exist to localize the blockage effectively, and to just far enough it won't inadvertently affect someone sitting in a restaurant harmlessly chatting on his/her cell phone beside the street or road as a car passes by?

I'm not trying to be nit-picky or obstinate, Bruce -- I really don't know the answers to those questions. If the answers are both "yes," then I fully agree. I've been arguing for such blocking in places such as movie theaters, live play venues, etc. for years.

If a doctor, say, wants to go watch a play, he/she can darned well let his/her nurse or whoever handles his incoming calls the telephone number of the theater, and let the workers there know who and where he/she is so they can quietly call him out if an emergency call come in during the performance.

Robert Ryan asks a good rhetorical question in his comment posted right after Bruce's, by the way.

If you truly believe Paul has no chance to win the nomination, you aren't paying attention. As a Gallup poll recently pointed out, a majority of Americans (68%) see big government as the #1 threat to the country. No other candidate comes close to representing an answer to the threat posed by Big Brother as does Ron Paul.

Ron Paul also has the best chance to beat Obama - as another recently poll indicated. This is because many Independents and Democrats are profoundly disappointed in Obama's failure to keep promises that were vitally important to them.

Obama promised to close Guantanamo, yet it remains open. Obama promised less war, but extended the occupation of Iraq, and added to that Afghanistan, Libya, and, now quite possibly Iran. Obama railed against Bush's State Secrets doctrine, only to invoke that very doctrine in federal court weeks after his inauguration. Obama signed an executive order claiming the right to keep people locked up for life AFTER acquittal. And soon, Obama will sign in to law renewal of the National Defense Authorization Act, which authorizes the military to arrest American citizens on American soil without charges and to hold them indefinitely with no opportunity to challenge the arrest or detention before a judge.

On the other hand, Ron Paul has an unassailable 30 record of unwavering opposition to unconstitutional militarism and defense of civil liberty. Independents and Democrats committed to peace and liberty will vote for him in droves.
